educational_objective: Diagnose Janeway lesions and recognize their association with infective endocarditis.
question_text: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of fever and malaise. A new heart murmur is auscultated. Today, crops of nonpainful cutaneous lesions have appeared on his feet.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is infective endocarditis (Option C). This patient's skin findings are Janeway lesions, which are nonpainful, erythematous, macular lesions located on the palms and soles and caused by septic emboli. This cutaneous finding is associated with infective endocarditis.
